title: Rikers replacement plan gets nod from Planning Commission, moves to City Council
text:
The plan calls for shuttering the troubled jail complex in the next seven years and developing new, smaller facilities to house the city’s jail population. | Bebeto Matthews/AP Photo, via pool Rikers replacement plan gets nod from Planning Commission, moves to City Council

The de Blasio administration’s plan to construct four new jail facilities to replace Rikers Island won City Planning Commission approval Tuesday, in a vote that was nearly drowned out by criminal justice activists who oppose the development of any new jails.

The proposal passed the body with nine votes in favor and three opposed, clearing a major hurdle in the land use approval process and ushering the hefty application into City Council review.

Story Continued Below

The plan calls for shuttering the troubled jail complex in the next seven years and developing new, smaller facilities to house the city’s jail population, which will have to be dramatically reduced in that time for it to work. The city would construct a new facility in every borough except Staten Island.

“This is among the most consequential applications to come before the City Planning Commission in years,” said commission Chair Marisa Lago during a public meeting Tuesday. “Today’s vote is so much more than a vote on site selections and special permits. It’s a vote to end a bleak era in New York City’s criminal justice history and a step towards critical criminal justice reform.”

Her remarks and the subsequent proceedings were continually interrupted by chants from members of the group No New Jails, which has been advocating against the closure plan.

The group argues the development of the new jails comes with no guarantee that Rikers will actually close, and that the funds required for the plan — currently estimated at $8.7 billion — should not be spent on perpetuating a system they consider inherently racist and violent.

Several commissioners who cast votes in approval said they remain concerned about aspects of the project, but feel the need to close the notoriously violent jail complex is too great to shoot the proposal down at this point.

“The site in the Bronx troubles me,” said Commissioner Allen Cappelli, echoing the opposition of Bronx Borough President Ruben Diaz Jr. and other elected officials from the borough who have repeatedly called on the city to select a different site for the Bronx facility. Still, Cappelli continued, “the overwhelming issue for me is closing Rikers Island.”

In a statement Tuesday, Diaz called the commission’s vote “unfortunate” and said the administration “has weaponized the land use process against The Bronx in order to protect their plans.”

Commissioners Orlando Marín, Raj Rampershad and Fred Cerullo — appointed to the body by the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island borough presidents, respectively — voted against the proposal.

While the local Council members who will ultimately need to green-light the proposal have been generally supportive of the closure plan, the range of continued opposition remains a hurdle to its final approval. The fight is shaping up to have implications in future races for local elected office, such as the special election for borough president taking shape in Queens, in anticipation of Melinda Katz potentially leaving the position to serve as district attorney.

In recommendations submitted earlier in the review process, the borough presidents and local community boards who weighed in raised concerns about the size of the proposed facilities and called for reductions.

Officials have modified the plans since earlier this year to reflect smaller facilities, following a lower estimate of the city’s eventual jail population in light of recent changes to the state's criminal justice system. The current population of Rikers hovers around 7,290 people, and officials estimate it will fall to 4,000 people by 2026.

Nevertheless, some community groups remain steadfastly opposed to the proposal.

“A number of the commissioners expressed serious reservations and concerns about this flawed application, from the use of design/build, to the site selection to the size, yet they chose to approve the plan, as is,” the Chinatown-based group Neighbors United Below Canal said in a statement on the commission vote. “This is NOT city planning but a rubber stamp.”

Criminal justice activists with the #CLOSErikers campaign, which has pushed for the effort, praised the commission’s decision. The group, however, is still calling for an accelerated closure plan and further reductions in the jail population than what the city is planning.

Some members of the group criticized the more vocal No New Jails activists on Tuesday.

“I’ve been on Rikers Island; a lot of these individuals that are saying ‘no new jails,’ they haven’t even been on a visit,” said Harvey Murphy, a Mott Haven resident who said he's served time at the complex. “I understand that in order to close Rikers we have to have something else.”

The proposal will come up for a City Council hearing on Sept. 5.
description: The plan calls for shuttering the troubled jail complex in the next seven years and developing smaller facilities to house the city’s jail population.
